choices.text: It should be started within 4 hours of receiving it from the blood bank.
It should be completed within 4 hours of receiving from the blood bank.
No such time restraint and can be done anytime.
It should be completed within 6 hours of receiving from the blood bank.

questions.text: What is correct regarding transfusion of the blood received from blood bank? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It should be completed within 4 hours of receiving from the blood bank.

 

Blood received from blood bank should be completely transfused within 4 hours of receiving.

 

Principles of blood administration:

 

  • All blood products should be given through an appropriate blood administration set containing a filter.
  • A careful aseptic technique should be practiced at all times.
  • Vital signs should be documented before and after transfusion and as clinically required. For the first 15 minutes after the infusion has begun, the patient should be kept under close observation to detect any signs of a serious transfusion reaction. If none is observed, the infusion rate may be increased.
  • One unit of red cells is often given in 1 to 4 hours, depending on the amount to be transfused and on the patient's cardiovascular status. Infusion of a unit for longer than 4 hours is not recommended, as there is a risk of bacterial proliferation because the opened unit is at room temperature.
  • No other solution and no medication should be added to or infused through the same tubing as a blood product.
  • Ringer's lactate or other solutions containing calcium must never be added to a blood product because the calcium present leads to coagulation.
  • After the transfusion has been completed, the transfusion tag or record should become part of the patient's chart.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It should be started within 4 hours of receiving it from the blood bank: This option is incorrect as the emphasis is on completing the transfusion within 4 hours, not just starting it.

 

Option C. No such time restraint and can be done anytime: This is incorrect, as there is a specific time frame to prevent bacterial proliferation.

 

Option D. It should be completed within 6 hours of receiving from the blood bank: This option is incorrect; the recommended maximum time for completion is 4 hours.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood transfusions must be completed within 4 hours of receiving the blood from the blood bank to minimize the risk of bacterial proliferation and ensure patient safety.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with widespread purpura and easy bruising. Laboratory tests reveal a significantly low platelet count with normal hemoglobin and white blood cell count, indicating a diagnosis of isolated thrombocytopenia. The patient has no prior history of autoimmune disorders or recent viral infections. Considering these symptoms and diagnosis, which tyrosine kinase inhibitor would be appropriate for this patient? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans B) Fostamatinib.

 

Fostamatinib is the suitable choice in this case. It is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor used specifically for the treatment of chronic immune thrombocytopenia (ITP), a condition characterized by isolated thrombocytopenia, which manifests as low platelet counts leading to symptoms like purpura and easy bruising. It operates by inhibiting spleen tyrosine kinase (Syk), thereby reducing the destruction of platelets and helping to increase the platelet count.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oprelvekin: Oprelvekin is not a tyrosine kinase inhibitor; it is a thrombopoietic growth factor used to increase platelet production, particularly in cases of chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia, rather than isolated thrombocytopenia without a clear underlying cause.

 

Option C. Eltrombopag: Eltrombopag is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist, not a tyrosine kinase inhibitor. It is used to treat thrombocytopenia, including ITP, but through a different mechanism - stimulating platelet production in the bone marrow.

 

Option D. Bosutinib: Bosutinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor; however, its primary use is in treating chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), not isolated thrombocytopenia or ITP. It targets the BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase, which is not involved in the pathology of ITP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fostamatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor specifically used for treating chronic immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) by inhibiting spleen tyrosine kinase (Syk) to reduce platelet destruction and increase platelet count.

questions.text: Which of the following sensations is not perceived by the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Proprioception

 

Explanation:

 

Proprioception refers to the sense of the relative position of body parts and the strength of effort being employed in movement. It provides the brain with information about limb position, movement, and force. It is perceived by the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, not the spinal nucleus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Temperature: Temperature sensation refers to the ability of the body to perceive differences in external and internal temperatures.

 

  • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve: The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve plays a key role in mediating temperature sensations from the face. It receives input from the descending or spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve for temperature sensation from the face.

 

Option B. Pain: Pain is an unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage.

 

  • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve: The spinal nucleus is responsible for pain sensation from the face. Pain fibers from the face descend along the spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve and synapse in the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Option C. Touch: Touch or tactile sensation refers to the ability of the body to perceive pressure or contact with the skin.

 

  • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve: Light touch from the face is also processed by the spinal nucleus, but it's worth noting that discriminative touch (ability to recognize specific shapes and textures) from the face is primarily processed by the main or chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, not the spinal nucleus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The trigeminal nerve consists of 4 nuclei:

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient presented with spikes of fever and difficulty in breathing. Transesophageal echo revealed vegetations in the heart. The culture was positive for Burkholderia cepacia. Which of the following is the first line of management? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cotrimoxazole with 3rd generation cephalosporins

 

The correct answer is B, Cotrimoxazole with 3rd generation cephalosporins. This combination is effective against Burkholderia cepacia, a pathogen known for its resistance to many standard antibiotics. The standard regimen includes Cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole), which has broad-spectrum bacterial coverage, combined with a 3rd generation cephalosporin such as ceftazidime or cefoperazone-sulbactam to cover for the pathogen's unique resistance profiles and aggressive infection nature, especially in immunocompromised patients or those with existing cardiac issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aminoglycoside and colistin: This option is incorrect due to the intrinsic resistance of Burkholderia cepacia to aminoglycosides. While colistin could still be effective, the resistance to aminoglycosides limits this combination's usefulness.

 

Option C. Carbapenems and 3rd generation cephalosporin: Incorrect because the combination of carbapenems with cephalosporins is generally not recommended. They both share a similar mechanism of action, inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis, and could potentially compete for the same binding sites, thus reducing their effectiveness.

 

Option D. Cefepime and tigecycline: Incorrect because tigecycline is not particularly effective against Burkholderia cepacia. Cefepime alone would not sufficiently manage the infection due to the bacteria's robust resistance profile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standard regimen for Burkholderia cepacia is cotrimoxazole with ceftazidime /cefoperazone-sulbactam.

choices.text: Life expectancy at birth, literacy and standard of living
Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and standard of living
Infant mortality rate, literacy and standard of living
Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and infant mortality rate

questions.text: You are a global health researcher working on a report assessing the development status of various countries. To classify the countries and compare them, you decide to use the Human Development Index (HDI). You recall that HDI is a commonly utilized measure but seek to clarify its exact components, as presented by organizations like the World Health Organization (WHO). Which of the following correctly identifies the components that make up the HDI? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Life expectancy at birth, literacy and standard of living 

 

Human Development Index (HDI)

 

The Human Development Index (HDI) is a composite statistic used to rank countries based on human development levels. It consists of three main components:

 

  • Life Expectancy at Birth: Measures the average number of years a newborn is expected to live.
  • Education (Literacy and Mean Years of Schooling): Assesses the average number of years of education received by people ages 25 and older and the expected years of schooling for children entering school.
  • Standard of Living (Gross National Income per capita): Adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP).

 

Note -

 

  • HDI values range: 0 to + 1
  • HDI India is 0. 633 (Rank 134 out of 186 countries)
  • Human poverty index [HPI] is complementary to HDI

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Conversion of pyruvate to Acetyl CoA
Conversion of pyruvate to Lactic acid

questions.text: Identify the anaplerotic reaction among the following? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conversion of pyruvate to Oxaloacetate

 

Anaplerotic reactions are “filling up” reactions or “influx” reactions or “replenishing” reactions which supply 4-carbon units to the TCA cycle.

 

The important anaplerotic reactions are:

 

  1. Pyruvate to oxaloacetate by pyruvate carboxylase enzyme. It needs ATP.
  2. Glutamate is transaminated to alpha keto glutarate; and aspartate to oxaloacetate.
  3. Pyruvate can be carboxylated to malate by NADP+ dependent malic enzyme.

 

The citric acid cycle acts as a source of precursors of biosynthetic pathways, e.g., heme is synthesized from succinyl CoA and aspartate from oxaloacetate. To counterbalance such losses, and to keep the concentrations of the 4-carbon units in the cell, anaplerotic reactions are essential. This is called anaplerotic role of TCA cycle (Greek word, ana = up; plerotikos = to fill)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conversion of pyruvate to Acetyl CoA: This is not an anaplerotic reaction; it is a part of the link between glycolysis and the TCA cycle.

 

Option C. Conversion of pyruvate to Acetaldehyde: This reaction is part of ethanol fermentation, not an anaplerotic reaction.

 

Option D. Conversion of pyruvate to Lactic acid: This is part of anaerobic glycolysis (fermentation), not an anaplerotic reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaplerotic reactions, such as the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, are crucial for maintaining the levels of TCA cycle intermediates, enabling the cycle to function efficiently and support biosynthetic demands.

questions.text: Bullet fingerprinting involves? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Both

 

Bullet fingerprinting / Ballistic finger printing:

 

  • Investigators using ballistic fingerprinting analyze a fired bullet or casing for scratches under a microscope. The markings, which — like fingerprints — are unique to each weapon, are then compared with those found on bullets used in separate shootings.
  • It involves both primary and secondary markings.

 

A. Primary markings (Class characteristics) occurs because bullet is slightly larger than the barrel. The primary markings are determined by Class characteristics are determined by manufacturing specifications, design and dimensions. They are most useful in identifying the make and model of the gun involved. Class characteristics in fired bullet identification would be:

 

i. Number, diameter and width of lands and grooves

ii. Depth of grooves

iii. Direction and degree of rifling twist

 

B. Secondary Markings (individual / accidental characteristics): These are formed due to Irregularities (imperfections) on the inner surface of barrel itself which are specific for that particular weapon. These irregularities are produced by sticking of particles of the bullet to the bore when shots are fired and is known as metallic fouling. They also result accidentally during the manufacturing process, usually microscopic in nature and have random distribution. They are useful in identifying the specific gun which was fired.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bullet fingerprinting utilizes both primary and secondary markings to identify a bullet, making it a comprehensive approach to forensic analysis in firearm-related investigations.

choices.text: Irrigation of eye with normal saline

questions.text: A patient presents with a foreign body (chuna) in his eyes and complains of irritability and lacrimation. What is the first step of management in this patient? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Irrigation of eye with normal saline

 

 

 

The initial management for any chemical injury to the eye, including chuna (lime) exposure, is immediate and copious irrigation with normal saline. This step is crucial to wash out the chemical substance from the eye to minimize further damage. Immediate irrigation helps dilute and remove the chemical agent, reducing the risk of severe injury to the ocular tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibiotics drops in eye: Antibiotic drops are important to prevent infection after the initial management, but they are not the first step. Irrigation must be done first to remove the chemical irritant.

 

Option B. Temporary tarsorrhaphy: Temporary tarsorrhaphy involves partially sewing the eyelids together to protect the eye, but this is not appropriate in the acute phase of a chemical injury. The eye needs to remain open to allow thorough irrigation and drainage of the chemical substance.

 

Option D. Complete Scraping: Complete scraping is a procedure to remove foreign particles embedded in the eye. While this might be necessary if there are chunks of chuna embedded in the conjunctiva, it is not the first step. The initial priority is to irrigate the eye to remove as much of the chemical as possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first step in the management of chemical injuries to the eye is immediate and copious irrigation with normal saline to wash out the chemical substance

questions.text: During a global health conference, you're in a discussion with fellow epidemiologists about the changing patterns of disease occurrence over the years. The conversation shifts towards the steady rise in non-communicable diseases over a considerable time span. One of your colleagues quizzes the group on the terminology for such a trend. Which term best describes this pattern of increasing prevalence over extended periods? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Secular 

 

  • This kind of pattern can be explained by secular trend.
  • Secular Trends (Long Term Fluctuations): Implies changes in occurrence of a disease (progressive increase or decrease) over a long period of time, generally several years or decades.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seasonal: Seasonal trends (Periodic fluctuations) is seasonal variation/fluctuation in occurrence of a disease. Examples: Measles (early spring), upper respiratory infection (winters), gastrointestinal infection (summer).

 

Option B. Cyclical: Cyclic trend (Periodic fluctuations) is occurrence of a disease in cycles spread over short periods of time, which may be days, weeks, months or years. Examples: Measles (every 2-3 years), Rubella (every 6-9 years), Influenza pandemics (every 10-15 years).

 

Option C. Periodic: Periodic fluctuations include both Seasonal and cyclical trends.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secular trends describe long-term changes in disease occurrence over years or decades, distinct from seasonal or cyclical variations.

questions.text: Match the characteristics resulting from the compression of the listed structures in the event of thyroid enlargement. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a

 

Explanation

 

  1. Trachea - c. Dyspnea (Difficulty Breathing): Thyroid enlargement can lead to the compression of the trachea (windpipe), causing narrowing of the airway. This compression can result in difficulty breathing, also known as dyspnea.
  2. Esophagus - d. Dysphagia (Difficulty Swallowing): When the thyroid gland enlarges and presses against the esophagus (the tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach), it can interfere with the normal swallowing process, leading to dysphagia or difficulty swallowing.
  3. Sympathetic Chain - b. Horner's Syndrome: Compression of the sympathetic chain, which runs along the sides of the neck, can result in Horner's syndrome. Horner's syndrome includes signs such as ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on one side of the face. Thyroid enlargement can affect sympathetic nerve fibers and lead to these symptoms.
  4. Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve - a. Hoarseness: The recurrent laryngeal nerve innervates the muscles responsible for vocal cord movement. Compression or damage to this nerve due to thyroid enlargement can result in hoarseness of voice and voice changes.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
A woman diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome has undergone a renal biopsy. All of the following statement(s) is/are true except? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. FSGS is not diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy.
  2. Patient should be observed for 24 hours following biopsy.
  3. Dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy indicate a hematoma.
  4. Patients with features of systemic amyloidosis and renal involvement should undergo renal biopsy.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 4

 

After an open or needle biopsy, patient will be kept in a recovery or an observation unit for 24 hours to monitor for potential complications, including pain and bleeding.

 

Bleeding and hematoma are the common complication of kidney biopsy. Patient can complain of blood or dark red clots in urine.

 

Statement 1. FSGS is not diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is diagnosed by biopsy for which a tissue sample is obtained by an invasive technique (percutaneous renal biopsy).

 

It's named "focal" because only some glomeruli are affected, and "segmental" because only parts of each glomerulus are affected, so biopsy is essential to catch it.

 

Statement 4. Patients with features of systemic amyloidosis and renal involvement should undergo renal biopsy: Renal venules are not affected in renal involvement in systemic amyloidosis. While a renal biopsy can confirm renal amyloid deposition, less invasive sites (like abdominal fat pad aspirate, rectal mucosa, or gingival biopsy) are often preferred first. Most commonly Abdominal fat pad biopsy is done.

 

Other Options

 

Statement 2. Patient should be observed for 24 hours following biopsy: After a renal biopsy, the patient should indeed be observed for 24 hours to monitor for potential complications like pain and bleeding.

 

Statement 3. Dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy indicate a hematoma: The presence of dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy is indicative of a hematoma, which is a common complication post-biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Percutaneous renal biopsy is a key diagnostic tool for conditions like FSGS, and proper post-procedure monitoring is essential to manage potential complications.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient comes to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of repetitive thoughts that, he always feels his hands are dirty, though they are not. This gives him discomfort and hence he has to wash them again and again. This is a disorder of thought:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Possession

 

The patient is experiencing obsessive thoughts. Obsessions are repetitive, intrusive, and unwanted thoughts that cause significant anxiety or distress. The individual recognizes that the obsessions are a product of his or her own mind, but they feel as though they can't control the thoughts, hence they fall under the category of disorders of thought possession.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Flow: Refers to the rate and speed of thoughts. Examples of disorders of flow include flight of ideas or inhibition of thinking.

 

Option B. Form: Refers to the organization and structure of thought. Examples of disorders of form include tangentiality, circumstantiality, and word salad.

 

Option D. Content: Refers to what person is actually thinking about, such as delusions.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Obsessions, as seen in obsessive-compulsive disorder, are considered disturbances of thought possession because while the individual recognizes the thoughts as their own, they feel as though they can't control them.

 

Reference: Fish’s Clinical Psychopathology, 4th edition, Page No 46.

choices.text: Naive B cells in Interfollicular zones

questions.text: Origin of B cell in CLL/SLL is: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Naive B cells in Interfollicular zones

 

In CLL/SLL, B cells originate from naive B cell or Pre/Post Germinal Centre memory B cell. CLL arises in the lymph node.

 

DNA sequencing has revealed that the Ig genes of some CLL/SLL are somatically hypermutated, whereas others are not, suggesting that the cell of origin may be either a post germinal center memory B cell or a naïve B cell. For unclear reasons, tumors with unmutated Ig segments (those putatively of naive B-cell origin) pursue a more aggressive course

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Centrocytes: Centrocytes are B cells located in the germinal center of lymphoid follicles, where they undergo selection during the immune response. However, they are not the origin of CLL/SLL, as CLL/SLL originates from naive B cells or memory B cells, not centrocytes.

 

Option B. Extranodal mature Peripheral B cells: While peripheral B cells are involved in immune responses, the origin of CLL/SLL is not from these mature peripheral B cells but rather from naive B cells within interfollicular zones.

 

Option D. Bone Marrow Progenitors: Bone marrow progenitors are the precursors of various blood cells, including B cells, but they are not the immediate origin of the B cells involved in CLL/SLL. CLL/SLL originates from more differentiated B cells, specifically naive B cells in interfollicular zones or memory B cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The origin of B cells in CLL/SLL is primarily from naive B cells in interfollicular zones or post-germinal center memory B cells. Tumors originating from naive B cells, as indicated by unmutated Ig segments, tend to pursue a more aggressive course.

questions.text: Which of the following is not caused by parvovirus B19?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Petechial rash

 

Parvovirus B19 is known to cause several conditions, including erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), which presents with a characteristic "slapped cheek" rash in children. It can also affect red blood cells, leading to pure red cell aplasia and aplastic crisis, especially in individuals with underlying hemolytic disorders. In pregnant women, parvovirus B19 infection can cause hydrops fetalis, a serious condition characterized by severe fetal anemia and fluid accumulation. However, petechial rash is not typically associated with parvovirus B19 infection. Petechial rashes are more commonly linked to other viral infections or conditions that cause thrombocytopenia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pure red cell aplasia: Parvovirus B19 can infect erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow, leading to pure red cell aplasia, particularly in individuals with compromised immune systems or underlying hematologic disorders.

 

Option B. Hydrops fetalis: Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can lead to hydrops fetalis due to severe fetal anemia, making this a well-documented complication.

 

Option C. Aplastic crisis: In individuals with chronic hemolytic anemias, such as sickle cell disease, parvovirus B19 infection can precipitate an aplastic crisis by temporarily halting red blood cell production in the bone marrow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 can cause pure red cell aplasia, aplastic crisis, and hydrops fetalis, but it is not associated with petechial rash.

questions.text:
A female with nephrotic syndrome underwent a renal biopsy. Which of the following statements is correct? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. FSGS cannot be diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy
  2. Patient should be observed for 24 hours following biopsy
  3. Dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy indicate a hematoma
  4. Patients with features of systemic amyloidosis and renal involvement can undergo abdominal fat pad biopsy instead of renal biopsy
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2,3,4

 

Following a renal biopsy, it is crucial to monitor the patient for potential complications, including bleeding and hematoma formation.

 

2. Observation post-biopsy: Patients should be observed for 24 hours following a renal biopsy to monitor for complications such as bleeding or infection.

 

3. Dark red clots in urine: Dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy can indicate a hematoma. This is a potential complication that needs to be monitored.

 

4. Abdominal fat pad biopsy: Patients with systemic amyloidosis and renal involvement can undergo an abdominal fat pad biopsy as an alternative to a renal biopsy. This method can help diagnose systemic amyloidosis with less risk compared to a renal biopsy.

 

Other Option:

 

1. FSGS cannot be diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy: This statement is incorrect. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) can indeed be diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy. The biopsy helps in identifying the characteristic histological changes associated with FSGS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-biopsy observation, recognition of biopsy-related complications, and alternative biopsy methods for systemic amyloidosis are essential in nephrotic syndrome management.

choices.text: All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotic
Caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space

questions.text: A 55-year-old female came to the hospital with a history of trauma to the ear. On examination, there is swelling, tenderness, and discoloration of the ear. Which of the following is false regarding the given image? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Resolves spontaneously

 

A hematoma of the auricle is depicted in the image given.

 

The scenario described seems to suggest a case of auricular hematoma, which is a collection of blood in the perichondrial space of the ear, usually following trauma. Here is a breakdown of the options provided:

 

This statement is false regarding Perichondral hematoma . If an Perichondral hematoma is left untreated, it usually does not resolve spontaneously. Instead, it often requires intervention to prevent complications such as infection or the development of 'Cauliflower ear'. The standard treatment involves aspiration of the hematoma or surgical intervention to prevent permanent deformity and to reestablish the connection between the cartilage and the overlying perichondrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotic: While not all cases may strictly require prophylactic antibiotics, they are often administered in practice to prevent infection, especially because the ear cartilage is avascular and therefore more susceptible to infection. The effectiveness of prophylactic antibiotics is debated, but it is a common practice, particularly when there's been a break in the skin.

 

Option B. May lead to Pugilistic ear: This is true. A 'Pugilistic ear' is another term for 'Cauliflower ear', which can occur if an auricular hematoma is not adequately treated, leading to fibrosis and cartilage deformity.

 

Option C. Caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space: This is correct. An auricular hematoma occurs when blood accumulates in the space between the cartilage and the perichondrium, which can occur after a blunt trauma to the ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perichondral hematoma (cauliflower ear, wrestler's ear, or pugilistic ear):

 

  • It is a deformity of the ear brought on by repeated trauma.
  • Perichondral space refers to the area of blood between the auricular cartilage and its perichondrium.
  • Due to blunt trauma, it is frequently observed in boxers, wrestlers, and rugby players.
  • It does not resolve spontaneously.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Prophylactic antibiotics should be administered in all cases.
  • Under strict aseptic guidelines, aspiration of the hematoma and application of a pressure dressing to stop re-accumulation.
  • Aspiration might have to be done again. Aspiration that doesn't work should be followed by incision and drainage.

 

Ref - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470424/

questions.text: Identify the type of skull fracture in the given image? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fissured 

 

Image shows thin lines, which are not displaced. This is characteristic of fissured (linear) #

 

Fissured (linear) fractures present as thin, non-displaced lines and are the most common type of skull fracture, typically resulting from broad surface impacts, such as in road traffic accidents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ring Fracture: Caused by a fall from height, presenting as a fracture around the foramen magnum.

 

Option B. Depressed Fracture: Caused by heavy objects with a small surface area, takes the shape of the weapon.

 

Option D. Hinge Fracture: Divides the skull into anterior and posterior halves, often associated with motorcyclist injuries.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Skull fractures 

 

  1. Linear fracture/ primary fracture/ fissured fracture                                                 
    • Fracture looks like a thin line 
    • Due to striking with a broad surface, e.g. ground 
    • Most common skull fracture, 
    • Usually seen in Road traffic accident
       

  2. Depressed fracture/ signature fracture 

    • Due to a heavy objects with small surface area . e.g. hammer 
    • Takes the shape of the weapon 

     

  3. Indented fracture / ping pong fracture / ponds #
    • Skull is depressed like a ping pong ball 
    • Seen in infants 
       
  4. Gutter fracture 
    • Long narrow depressed fracture 
    • Bullet passing adjacent to skull 
       
  5. Sutural fracture / diastatic fracture 
    • Sutures separate
    • Seen In <3 yrs of age 
       
  6. Ring fracture 
    • Cause – fall from height 
    • # around foramen magnum 
    • Associated # of vertebrae 
       
  7. Hinge fracture / motorcyclist fracture 
    • Skull divided into anterior and posterior halves 
       
  8. Spider web fracture / mosaic fracture / comminuted fracture 
    • Multiple fractures of skull

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with generalized fatigue, frequent urination, and increased thirst over the past few months. He mentions that he has also been experiencing muscle weakness and occasional abdominal discomfort. His abdomen spine X-ray shows the below finding. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperparathyroidism

 

The presented clinical scenario and X-ray reveal widespread calcification in both kidneys, indicating a condition known as nephrocalcinosis, often associated with hyperparathyroidism.

 

Nephrocalcinosis is characterized by the accumulation of calcium in the kidney parenchyma or tubules, and it commonly arises from conditions that lead to elevated calcium levels, such as hyperparathyroidism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wilson's disease: This is a genetic disorder that causes copper accumulation in tissues, leading to neurological and hepatic symptoms. It does not typically present with nephrocalcinosis or the specific set of symptoms described, such as muscle weakness and abdominal discomfort related to calcium imbalance.

 

Option B. Addison's disease: This condition involves adrenal insufficiency and can present with fatigue and abdominal pain but is not associated with nephrocalcinosis. It also does not explain the hypercalcemia indicated by kidney calcifications in the X-ray.

 

Option C. Cystic fibrosis: Primarily affects the lungs and digestive system, leading to thick mucus secretions and digestive complications. It is not associated with kidney calcifications or the hormonal imbalances of the parathyroid gland as seen in hyperparathyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Widespread kidney calcifications seen on X-ray, coupled with symptoms of fatigue, frequent urination, and increased thirst, are suggestive of hyperparathyroidism. This condition results from excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone, leading to elevated blood calcium levels and subsequent calcium deposition in organs like the kidneys (nephrocalcinosis).

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-d, 2-b, 3-c, 4-a

 

 

Silicosis (1-d): Silicosis is an occupational lung disease caused by the inhalation of silica dust, often found in industries like mining, sandblasting, and stone cutting. The term "crazy pavement" refers to a radiologic pattern seen in acute silicosis, which involves interstitial thickening and nodular fibrosis.

 

Mesothelioma (2-b): Mesothelioma is a malignant tumor of the pleura, most commonly associated with asbestos exposure. It typically presents with a pleural effusion that does not cause a mediastinal shift, distinguishing it from other causes of pleural effusion.

 

Caplan syndrome (3-c): Caplan syndrome is a combination of rheumatoid arthritis and pneumoconiosis (particularly coal workers' pneumoconiosis, also known as anthracosis). It was first identified in coal workers.

 

Asbestosis (4-a): Asbestosis is a lung disease resulting from the inhalation of asbestos fibers. It primarily affects the lower (basal) lobes of the lungs and can lead to fibrosis and increased risk of lung cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following shows functional assessment of B1 deficiency? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. RBC Transketolase

 

In thiamine deficiency, erythrocyte transketolase activity is reduced; this is the earliest manifestation seen even before clinical disturbances. Addition of thiamine diphosphate in vitro to erythrocyte lysate resulting in activation of apo transketolase is suggestive of B1 deficiency.

 

Thiamine contains a substituted pyrimidine ring connected to a substituted thiazole ring by means of methylene bridge. The vitamin is then converted to its active co-enzyme form by addition of two phosphate groups, with the help of ATP. It is catalyzed by thiamine pyrophosphotransferase.

 

Physiological Role of Thiamine

 

  1. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: The co-enzyme form is thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP). It is used in oxidative decarboxylation of alpha keto acids, e.g. pyruvate dehydrogenase catalyzes the breakdown of pyruvate, to acetyl CoA, and carbon dioxide
  2. Alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: An analogous biochemical reaction that requires TPP is the oxidative decarboxylation of alpha ketoglutarate to succinyl CoA and CO2
  3. Transketolase: The second group of enzymes that use TPP as co-enzyme are the transketolases, in the hexose monophosphate shunt pathway of glucose
  4. The main role of thiamine (TPP) is in carbohydrate metabolism. So, the requirement of thiamine is increased along with higher intake of carbohydrates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RBC Glutathione Reductase:

  • Function: Measures the activity of riboflavin (Vitamin B2).
  • Relevance: Used to assess riboflavin deficiency, not thiamine deficiency.

 

Option C. Serum Thiamine Levels:

  • Function: Direct measurement of thiamine in the blood.
  • Relevance: While it can indicate thiamine levels, it is less specific than functional assays like erythrocyte transketolase activity for assessing functional deficiency.

 

Option D. RBC Glutathione Peroxidase:

  • Function: Measures the activity of selenium and glutathione metabolism.
  • Relevance: Used to assess selenium status, not thiamine deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Sameer was tried in a court in the case of Sanjay’s murder in the park. Sahil appeared in court and stated that he saw Sameer with an axe in his hand while passing the park. What is this evidence known as? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Indirect

 

This type of evidence in known as an indirect evidence or circumstantial evidence.

 

This evidence providing only a basis for inference about the fact in dispute and it is not an eyewitness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hostile: Refers to a witness who is antagonistic or adverse to the party who called them to testify.

 

Option C. Direct: Evidence that directly proves a fact, such as an eyewitness account of the crime being committed.

 

Option D. Hearsay: Evidence based on what someone else said, not on the direct knowledge of the witness, and typically inadmissible in court due to its second-hand nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indirect or circumstantial evidence suggests a fact but does not directly prove it. In this case, seeing Sameer with an axe near the park suggests involvement but does not directly prove his guilt.

questions.text: The active site of enzyme is complimentary to: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Substrate

 

The active site of an enzyme is complementary to the substrate. The active site is a specific region of the enzyme where the substrate binds, forming an enzyme-substrate complex. This binding is highly specific and is often likened to a lock-and-key or induced-fit model. It provides a specific environment that facilitates the conversion of substrate into product.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transition state: The transition state refers to the intermediate state of a substrate as it undergoes a reaction and transforms into a product. While enzymes stabilize the transition state during catalysis, the active site itself is typically complementary to the substrate, not the transition state.

 

Option B. Allosteric activator: Allosteric activators bind to allosteric sites on enzymes, which are distinct from the active site. Allosteric regulation involves a change in the enzyme's conformation, affecting its activity.

 

Option D. Product: The active site is not complementary to the product. Once the reaction occurs, the product is released from the active site, allowing the enzyme to participate in another catalytic cycle with a new substrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective here is to understand the concept of the active site of an enzyme and its relationship to substrates. The active site of an enzyme is complimentary to the substrate, allowing specific interactions that enable the enzyme to catalyze a particular chemical reaction. It stabilizes the transition state of the reaction, facilitating the conversion of substrates into products.

questions.text: Which of the following will not commonly present as shown in the image below?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspergillus

 

The image shows a dermatophytic infection in the groin region called as Tinea cruris. Aspergillus species are not dermatophytes & are not associated with tinea infections.

 

This genus of fungi is not commonly involved in tinea infections. Aspergillus species are known to cause various diseases, primarily in the respiratory system, such as allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, aspergilloma, and invasive aspergillosis. They are not usually responsible for superficial skin infections like the one shown in the image.

 

Annular lesions are ring shaped with central clearing i.e., only the edges are active & appear raised, or in different color. It is present in granuloma annulare and tinea (Dermatophytic infection).

 

 

 

Dermatophytes include 3 genera:

 

  • ﻿﻿﻿Trichophyton species infect skin, hair and nails. E.g., T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, T. tonsurans, T. schoenleinii, T. violaceum, etc.
  • ﻿﻿﻿Microsporum contains M. gypseum, M. canis, and M. nanum. These infect only hair and skin (not nails).
  • ﻿﻿﻿Floccosum is the only species in the genus Epidermophyton, it infects only skin and nails (not hair).

 

Dermatophytes infect and survive only in the dead keratin layers of skin (stratum corneum), hair and nails as they are Keratinophilic.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichophyton:

 

  • Explanation: Trichophyton species are among the most common dermatophytes associated with Tinea cruris. They infect skin, hair, and nails and are known for their role in various forms of tinea, including Tinea cruris.
  • Why it could present as shown: Trichophyton often causes ring-shaped lesions with a clear center and scaly borders, matching the typical presentation of Tinea cruris.

 

Option B. Microsporum:

 

  • Explanation: While Microsporum primarily infects the hair and skin and is less commonly associated with Tinea cruris compared to Trichophyton, it can still cause dermatophytic infections of the groin.
  • Why it could present as shown: Microsporum can cause similar clinical manifestations as Trichophyton in Tinea infections, including red, itchy, and ring-shaped rashes.

 

Option D. Epidermophyton:

 

  • Explanation: Epidermophyton floccosum specifically targets the skin and nails and is a known causative agent of Tinea cruris. This fungus does not infect the hair, differentiating it from some other dermatophytes.
  • Why it could present as shown: Similar to other dermatophytes, Epidermophyton can cause the classic ring-shaped lesions of Tinea cruris with involvement of the groin area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspergillus species do not typically cause superficial skin infections such as tinea cruris; instead, they are more associated with respiratory system conditions. Trichophyton, Microsporum, and Epidermophyton are genera of fungi that commonly cause dermatophytosis like the tinea infections seen in the presented image.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4. Page no 4.11, 4.13

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.18-20

Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 9th edition Page no 599

questions.text: Earliest sign of compartment syndrome of leg is:(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pain on passive stretch

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndrome, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.
  • Most commonly compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).
  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.
  • Most common cause is fractures and dislocations.
  • Other causes of compartment syndrome are:
    • Crush injury/Burn/Infection/Surgical procedure/Tight circumferential dressing
    • Exercise: Exercise may increase intracompartmental pressure and muscle edema, so it is avoided in cases of acute compartmental syndrome.
  • Clinical Features:
    • The diagnosis of compartment syndrome is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.
    • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) (1st sign).
    • In compartment syndrome the order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intracompartmental pressure is: capillary compression, venous compression, arterial compression.
    • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome. The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
    • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.
    • Pressures in the deep volar compartment are significantly elevated compared with pressures in other compartments. Deep flexor muscles are involved particularly flexor digitorum profundus > flexor pollicis longus.
  • Treatment: 
    • The limb should be kept at the level of heart rather than elevated.
    • Removal of all circumferential dressing reduce pressure up to 85%.
    • Fasciotomy is recommended in the presence of clinical signs of compartment syndrome, such as undue pain and a palpable firmness in the forearm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tingling or numbness. Paresthesia, tingling or numbness occur in the late stages.

 

Option D. Pulselessness. It is also the late feature. Presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The first sign of compartment syndrome is the pain and resistance to the passive stretch of the distal-most joint of the extremity.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes develops a UTI, which gets complicated with hypotension that is resistant to IV fluids. Which of the following antibiotics can be used? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Piperacillin-Tazobactam

 

The patient with diabetes has developed a urinary tract infection (UTI) complicated by hypotension resistant to IV fluids, indicating septic shock. In cases of septic shock, it is critical to start with empirical broad-spectrum antibiotics. These antibiotics are designed to cover a wide range of potential pathogens until the specific causative organism can be identified and targeted.

 

Broad-spectrum antibiotics suitable for such severe infections include:

 

  • Piperacillin-Tazobactam
  • Carbapenems like Meropenem or Imipenem
  • Certain third-generation cephalosporins like Ceftazidime

 

In this case, Piperacillin-Tazobactam is chosen because it is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that covers many of the common pathogens responsible for severe infections and septic shock. Although a combination of Meropenem with Vancomycin would be ideal, the given options do not include Meropenem. Therefore, Piperacillin-Tazobactam is the best choice among the provided options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amoxicillin-Clavulanate: This antibiotic is generally not sufficient for treating severe infections or septic shock due to its narrower spectrum of activity compared to Piperacillin-Tazobactam.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: While Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin, it is not as broad-spectrum as Ceftazidime and does not provide the same coverage needed for septic shock.

 

Option D. Nitrofurantoin: This antibiotic is typically used for uncomplicated lower urinary tract infections and is not effective for severe systemic infections or septic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of septic shock, especially in a patient with diabetes and complicated UTI, broad-spectrum antibiotics such as Piperacillin-Tazobactam are critical for empirical therapy.

choices.text: Can be used for screening mammographically undetectable or clinically non palpable breast mass
Useful in young females with dense breast
Differentiates between solid and Cystic lesions in the Breast

questions.text: Which of the following isn't considered a benefit of USG compared to Mammography?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Can be used for screening mammographically undetectable clinically non palpable breast mass

 

Ultrasound has no role in detecting non-palpable breast cancers.

 

Ultrasound is particularly useful in young women with dense breasts in whom mammograms are difficult to interpret, and in distinguishing cysts from solid lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Useful in young females with dense breast: Ultrasound is indeed beneficial in young women with dense breast tissue where mammograms can be harder to interpret due to the denseness of the tissue obscuring the view of potential abnormalities.

 

Option C. Differentiates between solid and Cystic lesions in the Breast: Ultrasound is particularly effective in distinguishing between solid and cystic lesions within the breast. This ability is crucial for determining the nature of a breast mass and guiding further diagnostic and treatment actions.

 

Option D. Guided biopsy can be done: Ultrasound-guided biopsy is a well-established procedure that uses ultrasound imaging to guide the needle to the precise location of the abnormal tissue in the breast for sampling. This is particularly useful for targeting lesions that are visible on ultrasound but not palpable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ultrasound should not be considered a standalone screening tool for non-palpable breast masses or those not detected by mammography. However, it is invaluable in specific scenarios such as evaluating women with dense breasts, distinguishing between cystic and solid breast lesions, and facilitating guided biopsies.

questions.text: Identify the helminth from the life cycle given below? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The image shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

The infective form of strongyloides is the filariform larva. Infection occurs through penetration of the skin by larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma duodenale: This is another helminth with a similar skin-penetrating infection method, but its life cycle is characterized by direct development into adult worms in the intestine after migration, without a free-living phase.

 

Option C. Ascaris lumbricoides: This helminth has a different life cycle involving the ingestion of eggs, which then hatch in the intestine, and larvae migrate through the liver and lungs before maturing in the intestine.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis: Known as pinworm, this helminth has a life cycle involving the ingestion of eggs, which hatch in the intestine, and the adult worms live in the colon and rectum.

 

Educational Objective:


Strongyloides stercoralis infects through skin penetration by filariform larvae from contaminated soil.

questions.text: Identify the pelvic diaphragm in the picture given below: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

The structure marked "A" is the levator ani muscle which is the component of pelvic diaphragm.

 

Other structures marked in the above image are:

 

B: External anal sphincter

C: Obturator internus

D: Perianal fascia

 

Pelvic diaphragm -

 

The pelvic diaphragm is the muscular part of the pelvic floor. It connects to the pelvic wall on both sides, between the greater and lesser sciatic foramen. The pelvic diaphragm is formed by the levator ani and coccyges muscles, which define the lower limit of the true pelvis.

 

 

Pubococcygeus, iliococcygeus, and puborectalis combine to form Levator ani. The muscles in both sexes blend together posterior to the vagina and around the anus. The form in which the anococcygeal body attaches to the coccyx posterior to the anal aperture.

 

Urogenital hiatus is present anteriorly separating the muscles. This allows the urethra and vagina to pass through. Levator ani reinforces the external anal sphincter. In women, it functions as the vaginal sphincter.

 

The coccyges muscles are triangular in shape and form the posterior part of the pelvic diaphragm, one on each side. The apices are attached to the ischial spine tips. The bases connect to the coccyx and sacrum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphincter Ani Externus (External Anal Sphincter): This is a circular muscle that surrounds the anus. It's located below the level of the levator ani. It is innervated by the pudendal nerve, allowing for voluntary control over defecation.

 

Option C. Obturator Muscle: This term often refers to two muscles - obturator externus and obturator internus. They are situated on either side of the obturator membrane in the pelvis. Obturator Externus: Obturator nerve and Obturator Internus: Nerve to obturator internus (a branch of the sacral plexus).

 

Option D. Perianal Fascia: The perianal fascia is not a muscle but is the connective tissue located in the perianal region, around the anus. It's part of the deeper layers of the skin in this region.  It's associated with various potential spaces that can become sites of abscess formation if there's an infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The levator ani is the principal muscle of the pelvic floor and is composed of three parts: the puborectalis, the pubococcygeus, and the iliococcygeus. It is primarily innervated by the pudendal nerve and the S4 nerve root.

choices.text: A patient who is in acute crisis
A patient who is severely ill with deficient ego functioning
A patient with strong ego and high motivation

questions.text: In which of the following patients, supportive psychotherapy would not be preferred? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A patient with strong ego and high motivation

 

A patient with strong ego and high motivation: Advanced psychoanalysis are advised due to the patient's capacity for deep psychological work. Supportive psychotherapy, which focuses on immediate coping, is considered less effective for this patient.

 

Supportive psychotherapy is aimed at supporting the patient through reassurance, guidance, and a therapeutic relationship without delving deeply into their past or cognitive processes. It is particularly useful for patients in acute crisis, those with cognitive deficits, and severely ill patients with deficient ego functioning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A patient who is in acute crisis: Supportive psychotherapy is highly appropriate as it focuses on providing immediate support and reassurance without exploring complex underlying issues.

 

Option B. A patient with cognitive deficits: These patients may struggle to understand more intricate forms of psychotherapy, making supportive psychotherapy a suitable option to provide essential support and stabilization.

 

Option C. A patient who is severely ill with deficient ego functioning: These patients often have low frustration tolerance and cannot handle the complexities of other forms of therapy, making supportive psychotherapy beneficial to provide stability and support.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supportive psychotherapy is not preferred for patients with a strong ego and high motivation, as they can handle and benefit from more complex and deeper forms of therapy.

questions.text: Eicosanoids are formed from:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arachidonic acid

 

Eicosanoids are derived from arachidonic acid, which is a polyunsaturated fatty acid found in cell membranes. Arachidonic acid serves as the precursor for eicosanoid synthesis when it is released from membrane phospholipids through the action of enzymes such as phospholipase A2. Once released, arachidonic acid can be metabolized into various eicosanoids, including prostaglandins, leukotrienes, and thromboxanes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Platelet aggregation: Platelet aggregation refers to the process of blood platelets clumping together. While eicosanoids can influence platelet aggregation by promoting or inhibiting it, they are not formed directly from platelet aggregation. Platelet aggregation involves the activation of platelets and the release of various signaling molecules, including some eicosanoids, as part of the clotting process.

 

Option C. 4 fused rings: Eicosanoids are not characterized by having four fused rings. Instead, they are typically small molecules with a 20-carbon backbone structure.

 

Option D. Arginine: Arginine is an amino acid and is not directly involved in the formation of eicosanoids. Eicosanoids are primarily derived from arachidonic acid, as mentioned earlier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eicosanoids are bioactive lipid molecules that play a crucial role in various physiological processes in the body. They are formed from arachidonic acid. Arachidonic acid has (20 C, 4=) and is synthesized from linoleic acid. Eicosanoids (Prostaglandins and leukotrienes) are synthesized from arachidonic acid. So, Linoleic acid is considered as most essential fatty acid.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 224

questions.text: A 75-year-old female had a fall and had intertrochanteric fracture. This is due to:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Osteoporosis

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology of Osteoporosis:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.
    • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate

 

 

Codfish Vertebrae (Osteoporosis/Osteomalacia)

 

Note: Intertrochanteric hip fractures are the most commonly occurring fractures in the elderly osteoporotic population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Osteopetrosis. This disease is commonly seen in children. It is a diaphyseal dysplasia characterized by failure of bone resorption due to functional deficiency of osteoclast. Due to functional deficiency of osteoclasts, calcified chondroid (cartilage) and primitive woven bone persists down into metaphysis and diaphysis, leading to osteosclerosis and increased brittleness of bones (marble bone disease). Autosomal dominant osteopetrosis is diagnosed in adult asymptomatic patients. It may present with mild anemia, pathological fractures premature osteoarthritis, and rarely osteomyelitis of mandible. Autosomal recessive malignant (congenital) osteopetrosis clinically presents at birth or in early infancy because of obliteration of marrow cavity by bony overgrowth resulting in inability of bone marrow to participate in hematopoiesis. Pancytopenia develops resulting in abnormal bleeding, easy bruising, progressive anemia, and failure to thrive. Laboratory parameters are serum calcium low, serum PTH high, serum phosphate low and serum ALP high. Radiological hallmark is increased radiopacity of bones. There is no distinction between cortical and cancellous bone, because intramedullary canal is filled with bone. Endobones (os in os or bone within bone appearance) and rugger jersey spine are seen on radiographs. Treatment is bone marrow transplant.

 

 

Option C. Paget’s disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. Osteoclast appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. The new bone formed is abnormal, very vascular and larger (deforms and fractures) than preexisting bone, which leads to cortical widening and deformity. The diagnostic histological feature of Paget's disease is irregular area of lamellar bone fitting together like a jigsaw with randomly distributed cement lines. Initial osteolytic phase involves prominent bone resorption and marked hypervascularization (Radiologically seen as advancing lytic wedge or blade of grass lesion). 2nd phase of active bone formation and resorption replaces normal lamellar bone with structurally weak woven bone that bend, bow and fracture easily. In 3rd sclerotic (burnt out) phase, bone resorption declines progressively and leads to hard, dense, less vascular pagetic or mosaic bone. Most people are asymptomatic. The sites most commonly involved are pelvis, tibia, followed by skull, spine, clavicle and femur. It affects men (> 50 years) more commonly. Pain is most common presenting symptom. Limb looks bent and feels thick, and skin is unduly warm due to high vascularity.

 

 

Blade of grass

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hip fractures are most commonly seen in elderly females due to osteoporosis.

questions.text: Which is a mood stabilizer with an anti-suicidal role? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lithium

 

Lithium is the only mood stabilizer that has been consistently shown to have an anti-suicidal effect in patients with bipolar disorder and major depressive disorder. Numerous studies have demonstrated that lithium reduces the risk of suicide and suicide attempts. It is considered the gold standard for mood stabilization, particularly in bipolar disorder, due to its efficacy in preventing both manic and depressive episodes.

 

Mechanism of Lithium:

 

  • Mood Stabilization: Lithium modulates neurotransmission by affecting various neurotransmitter pathways, including serotonin and norepinephrine.
  • Neuroprotective Effects: Lithium enhances neurogenesis and has neuroprotective effects, potentially contributing to its anti-suicidal properties.
  • Reduction in Aggression and Impulsivity: Lithium has been shown to reduce aggression and impulsivity, which are risk factors for suicide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carbamazepine: Carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant and mood stabilizer used to treat bipolar disorder, particularly in patients with rapid cycling or mixed states. However, it does not have a proven anti-suicidal effect.

 

Option B. Lamotrigine: Lamotrigine is effective as a mood stabilizer, particularly in preventing depressive episodes in bipolar disorder. While it helps in mood stabilization, it does not have a specific anti-suicidal effect.

 

Option D. Valproate: Valproate is another anticonvulsant and mood stabilizer used in bipolar disorder, especially effective in rapid cyclers. It does not have an established anti-suicidal role.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lithium is unique among mood stabilizers for its anti-suicidal properties. It significantly reduces the risk of suicide and is effective in stabilizing mood in patients with bipolar disorder and major depressive disorder. Valproate is the drug of choice in rapid cyclers, whereas Lamotrigine is effective as a mood stabilizer in Depression.

questions.text: The enzyme kinetics depicted in the Graph is suggestive of:(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Michaelis Menten kinetics

 

Explanation:

 

The graph shows a hyperbola which is suggestive of Michaels - Menten Kinetics of the enzyme.

 

Here, Vmax represents the maximum rate achieved by the system, happening at saturating substrate concentration for a given enzyme concentration. When the value of the Michaelis constant Km is numerically equal to the substrate concentration, then the reaction rate is half of Vmax. Biochemical reactions involving a single substrate are often assumed to follow Michaelis–Menten kinetics.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Allosteric Activation: This typically results in a sigmoid (S-shaped) curve rather than a hyperbolic one, as allosteric enzymes exhibit cooperative binding.

 

Option B. Cooperative Binding: This is also characterized by a sigmoid curve, indicating that the binding of substrate to one active site affects the binding at other active sites.

 

Option D. Sigmoid Curve: This type of curve is associated with allosteric enzymes and cooperative binding, not with Michaelis-Menten kinetics.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Michaelis-Menten kinetics is characterized by a hyperbolic curve where Vmax is the maximum rate achieved, and Km is the substrate concentration at which the reaction rate is half of Vmax.

questions.text: Name the location of the nucleus supplying the muscle marked with the question mark in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superior colliculus

 

The highlighted muscle is the medial rectus, which is supplied by the oculomotor nerve. The nucleus of the oculomotor nerve is situated at the level of the superior colliculus. The oculomotor nerve arises from a nuclear complex that includes the oculomotor nucleus and Edinger-Westphal preganglionic nucleus. The oculomotor nucleus is comprised of several groups of large motor neurons that innervate the ipsilateral inferior rectus, inferior oblique, and medial rectus in dorsoventral order. Additionally, a column of cells located medially innervates the contralateral superior rectus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior olivary: This is part of the auditory pathway and has no involvement in eye muscle control.

 

Option B. Inferior colliculus: Also part of the auditory pathway, located in the midbrain but not involved in motor control of eye movements.

 

Option D. Fascial colliculus: This term is likely a typographical error for "facial colliculus," which refers to a structure in the brainstem associated with the facial nerve, not the oculomotor nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nucleus of the oculomotor nerve, responsible for innervating the medial rectus muscle among others, is located at the level of the superior colliculus in the midbrain. This is crucial for understanding the neural control of eye movements, particularly in how various components of the eye are coordinated for proper visual alignment and focus.

questions.text: What type of mutation is seen in sickle cell anemia? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Point mutations

 

Sickle cell anemia is caused due to a point mutation in B globin gene wherein adenine is replaced with thymine in the 6th codon of DNA sequence. Thus, the glutamic acid in the 6th position of beta chain of HbA is changed to valine in HbS. This single amino acid substitution leads to polymerization of hemoglobin molecules inside RBCs. This causes a distortion of cell into sickle shape.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insertion: An insertion mutation involves the addition of one or more nucleotide base pairs into the DNA sequence. This type of mutation is not responsible for sickle cell anemia.

 

Option B. Deletion: A deletion mutation involves the removal of one or more nucleotide base pairs from the DNA sequence. This type of mutation is not responsible for sickle cell anemia.

 

Option D. Frameshift mutation: A frameshift mutation is caused by insertions or deletions of a number of nucleotides that are not divisible by three, resulting in a shift in the reading frame of the codons in the DNA sequence. This type of mutation is not responsible for sickle cell anemia.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text:
Which of the following cyanotic heart diseases causes increased pulmonary blood flow? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Ebstein anomaly
  2. Tetralogy of Fallot
  3. Transposition of the great arteries (TGA)
  4. Total anomalous pulmonary venous communication (TAPVC)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3, 4

 

Transposition of the great arteries (TGA) and total anomalous pulmonary venous communication (TAPVC) are both cyanotic congenital heart diseases that cause increased pulmonary blood flow.

 

3. Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA): In TGA, the positions of the pulmonary artery and the aorta are switched, which results in deoxygenated blood being circulated throughout the body. The mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood occurs, leading to increased pulmonary blood flow because the deoxygenated blood is directed to the lungs.

 

4. Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Communication (TAPVC): In TAPVC, the pulmonary veins do not connect normally to the left atrium. Instead, they connect to the right atrium or systemic veins, causing a mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. This also leads to increased blood flow to the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 4: Ebstein anomaly does not cause increased pulmonary blood flow. Ebstein anomaly involves downward displacement of the tricuspid valve, leading to decreased pulmonary blood flow.

 

Option B. 1, 2: Both Ebstein anomaly and Tetralogy of Fallot cause decreased pulmonary blood flow. Tetralogy of Fallot includes pulmonary stenosis, which limits blood flow to the lungs.

 

Option D. 2, 4: Tetralogy of Fallot causes decreased pulmonary blood flow due to the presence of pulmonary stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyanotic congenital heart diseases such as Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) and Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Communication (TAPVC) cause increased pulmonary blood flow.

choices.text: Endobronchial neoplasm
Bronchial asthma
Myasthenia gravis

questions.text: The flow volume curve after spirometry in patient 1 is given below. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myasthenia gravis

 

In patient 1, flow volume curve shows restrictive pattern, and it corresponds to myasthenia gravis.

 

The flow volume curve shown indicates a restrictive pattern, which is characterized by reduced lung volumes but relatively preserved flow rates, consistent with non-obstructive lung pathology. Myasthenia gravis, a neuromuscular disorder, often affects the respiratory muscles leading to a restrictive ventilatory defect as depicted in the flow volume loop. This condition results from antibodies that block or destroy nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the junction between the nerve and muscle, leading to muscle weakness including the respiratory muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endobronchial neoplasm: Typically presents with an obstructive pattern on spirometry due to airway obstruction.

 

Option B. Bronchial asthma: Asthma would show an obstructive pattern characterized by decreased peak expiratory flow and difficulty exhaling, which is not observed in the given curve.

 

Option D. Emphysema: Emphysema, part of chronic obstructive pulmonary diseases (COPD), would also exhibit an obstructive pattern with a "scooped out" appearance on the expiratory curve due to air trapping and reduced elastic recoil, which is not seen in the curve provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis can present with a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests due to respiratory muscle weakness, differentiating it from conditions that cause obstructive patterns such as asthma and emphysema.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient undergoes parotidectomy surgery to remove a tumor. During the postoperative period, the patient complains of loss of sensation while shaving. Which nerve is most likely affected in this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Great auricular nerve

 

The great auricular nerve is a branch of the cervical plexus (specifically, the cervical spinal nerves C2 and C3). It provides sensory innervation to the skin of the earlobe and the skin over the parotid gland. Damage to this nerve during parotidectomy surgery can lead to loss of sensation in the earlobe area, which could affect the patient's sensation while shaving.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Auriculotemporal nerve: The auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of the mandibular nerve (a branch of the trigeminal nerve). It provides sensory innervation to the skin of the external ear and the temporal region, which if injured gives rise to gustatory sweating or Frey’s syndrome.

 

Option C. Facial nerve: The facial nerve is responsible for motor control of the muscles of facial expression, not sensation. Damage to the facial nerve during parotidectomy surgery can result in facial weakness or paralysis rather than altered sensation.

 

Option D. Marginal mandibular nerve: The marginal mandibular nerve is a branch of the facial nerve and primarily provides innervation to the lower lip. It is not typically involved in sensation during shaving.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nerves that can be injured in parotidectomy and its significance:

 

A) Auriculotemporal nerve injury – Frey’s syndrome

 

B) Great auricular nerve- loss of sensation in area of shaving

 

C) Facial nerve- facial palsy

questions.text: Marked structure is derived from the?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Endocardial cushions

 

Explanation:

 

The interventricular septum's membranous portion is the indicated structure. It comes from the endocardial cushions.

 

 

  • Endocardial cushions are soft tissue masses that protrude in the atrioventricular and conotruncal regions.
    • Atrioventricular cushions are derived from overlying endocardial cells.
    • The conotruncal cushions are derived from the neural crest cells.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Septum primum: The septum primum is involved in the development of the atrial septum, not the interventricular septum. It forms a temporary structure in the embryonic heart that helps separate the atria.

 

Option C. Left venous valve: The left venous valve is not directly involved in the formation of the interventricular septum. It is a structure found within the embryonic heart that helps direct oxygenated blood from the left atrium into the left ventricle.

 

Option D. Bulbous venosus: The bulbous venosus is an embryonic structure that contributes to the formation of the smooth part of the right ventricle. It is not associated with the development of the interventricular septum.

 

 

Cardiac abnormalities, such as ASs, VSDs, and anomalies affecting the major arteries, can be caused by errors in the creation of the endocardial cushion (transposition of the great vessels, common truncus arterious, and tetralogy of Fallot).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endocardial cushions contribute to the formation of:

 

  1. Atrial septa
  2. Ventricular septa (membranous portion)
  3. Atrioventricular canals
  4. Atrioventricular valves

 

The membranous portion of the interventricular septum develops from the endocardial cushions.

questions.text: A patient undergoes thyroid surgery, and their surgeon is aiming to minimize nerve injury during the procedure. Which of the following nerves is least likely to be injured during thyroid surgery? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Marginal mandibular nerve

 

The marginal mandibular nerve is located in the lower part of the face, near the mandible. It is not directly associated with thyroid surgery and is far less likely to be injured during the procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrent laryngeal nerve: The recurrent laryngeal nerve is one of the most critical nerves to be cautious of during thyroid surgery. It runs near or through the thyroid gland and is vulnerable to injury in region of Berry’s ligament.

 

Option B. Ansa cervicalis: The ansa cervicalis is a nerve loop formed by cervical spinal nerves. While it may be in the vicinity of thyroid surgery, it is less likely to be directly affected by the procedure compared to other nearby nerves like the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Option C. External laryngeal nerve: The external laryngeal nerve is also in the vicinity of thyroid surgery and is most commonly injured during thyroid surgery. Its main function is to supply the cricothyroid muscle.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The marginal mandibular nerve is the nerve least likely to be injured during thyroid surgery.
  • The nerve is high up, closer to the mandibular margin.
  • The ansa cervicalis may be injured if the strap muscles are not cut high enough during surgery.
  • The superior laryngeal nerve may be injured near the superior pole of the thyroid.
  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve may be injured if dissection is done below the cricoid cartilage or near the tracheoesophageal groove

questions.text: Identify the condenser? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) B

 

B: The condenser is located beneath the microscope stage and is used to focus light onto the specimen. It typically contains lenses that gather and concentrate light from the illuminator and direct it through the specimen for optimal viewing.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. A: This is the coarse focusing knob, which is used to bring the specimen into general focus by moving the stage up and down.

 

Option B. C: This represents the objective lenses, which are used to magnify the specimen.

 

Option D. D: This is the illuminator, which is the light source that provides illumination for viewing the specimen.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text:
Out of the below mentioned statements regarding anterior shoulder dislocation, true statements are: 

 

  1. Recurrence rate is maximum if the patient's age is less than 20 years.
  2. Axillary nerve is most commonly injured.
  3. CT scan is preferred for knowing the bony lesion.
  4. Anterior shoulder dislocation is the most common type.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

1. Recurrence rate is maximum if the patient's age is less than 20 years: The recurrence rate for anterior shoulder dislocation is indeed highest among younger patients, particularly those under the age of 20. Statistics show that the recurrence rate is 55% for those aged 12 to 22, 37% for ages 23 to 29, and only 12% for ages 30 to 40. The higher recurrence in younger patients is attributed to increased joint laxity and higher activity levels.

 

2. Axillary nerve is most commonly injured: Axillary nerve injury is the most frequent complication following an anterior shoulder dislocation. The nerve, which innervates the deltoid muscle and provides sensation to the lateral aspect of the upper arm, is highly vulnerable because of its anatomical location. Injury can result in deltoid muscle paralysis and loss of sensation over a small area on the shoulder.

 

3. CT scan is preferred for knowing the bony lesion: A three-dimensional computed tomography (CT) scan is the preferred imaging technique for detecting osseous (bony) lesions and quantifying the extent of bone loss. It is more accurate than X-rays for assessing fractures and bone integrity and is considered the gold standard for evaluating bone-related pathologies.

 

4. Anterior shoulder dislocation is the most common type: Anterior shoulder dislocation is far more common than posterior dislocation. It often occurs due to trauma that forces the shoulder into abduction and external rotation. The anterior glenoid rim can become rounded or worn down over time if the dislocation is recurrent. Anterior dislocations account for the majority of shoulder dislocation cases in adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior shoulder dislocation is the most common type, has the highest recurrence rate in patients under 20 years, commonly results in axillary nerve injury, and requires a CT scan for accurate evaluation of bony lesions.
