choices.text: Alternative RNA splicing

questions.text: Due to which phenomenon, B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies at the same time? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alternative RNA splicing

 

B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies at the same time due to alternative RNA splicing.

 

Alternative splicing is the process that selectively removes introns or exons, or parts thereof, to generate multiple messenger RNAs (mRNAs) from a single precursor mRNA (pre-mRNA).

 

Humoral immunity is mediated by antibodies, which are produced by B lymphocytes.

 

Upon maturation, B lymphocytes produce IgM as the first type of immunoglobulin, followed by immunoglobulin IgG, IgE, and IgA, as a result of irreversible rearrangement of the immunoglobulin gene after activation.

 

In contrast, the IgM-to-IgD transition is produced through alternative splicing of a long primary mRNA transcript from the Ig heavy chain gene, IGH. The nuclear RNA-binding protein, HuR, is well known for its function in mRNA splicing and nuclear export.

 

Other options:

 

Options A. Somatic hypermutation and C. Affinity maturation: Affinity maturation is the process by which antibodies gain increased affinity, avidity, and anti-pathogen activity and is the result of somatic hypermutation (SHM) of immunoglobulin genes in B cells, coupled to selection for antigen binding.

 

Option D. Allelic exclusion: Allelic exclusion is a process by which only one allele of a gene is expressed while the other allele is silenced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

B cells express both IgM and IgD through alternative RNA splicing, allowing the simultaneous expression of these two immunoglobulins.

questions.text: The given life cycle belongs to which of the following organisms? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leptospira

 

The life cycle shown in the images is indicative of leptospirosis, a zoonotic disease caused by bacteria of the genus Leptospira. The diagram highlights the transmission cycle involving various animal reservoirs and the environment, which is characteristic of leptospirosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hanta virus: Transmitted through aerosolized rodent excreta but does not fit the detailed transmission cycle depicted in the image.

 

Option C. Yersinia pestis: Causes plague, transmitted primarily through fleas, and does not follow the environmental cycle shown in the image.

 

Option D. Salmonella typhi: Causes typhoid fever, transmitted through ingestion of contaminated food and water, and does not have a life cycle involving animal reservoirs as depicted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The life cycle of Leptospira involves transmission from animal reservoirs through contaminated water and soil, leading to human infection, which fits the depiction in the provided images.

choices.text: Hypertension diagnosed at 10 weeks of gestation

questions.text: Pregnant women with which of the following is called systemic hypertension? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypertension diagnosed at 10 weeks of gestation

 

Explanation:

 

Systemic hypertension in pregnancy is classified as chronic hypertension if it is diagnosed in the first trimester or if hypertension persists beyond 12 weeks postpartum. Hypertension present before pregnancy or diagnosed before the 20th week of gestation also qualifies as chronic hypertension. This is distinct from gestational hypertension, which develops after 20 weeks of gestation in a previously normotensive woman.

 

  • Chronic Hypertension: Defined as blood pressure of ≥ 140/90 mm Hg that was present before pregnancy or diagnosed before the 20th week of gestation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diabetic retinopathy: This condition is a complication of diabetes affecting the eyes, not a direct indicator of systemic hypertension.

 

Option C. Diabetic nephropathy: This is a complication of diabetes that affects the kidneys and can be associated with hypertension, but it is not specific to the definition of systemic hypertension in pregnancy.

 

Option D. Episode of seizure: Seizures in the context of pregnancy are associated with eclampsia, a severe form of preeclampsia, but do not directly define systemic hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systemic hypertension in pregnancy is diagnosed if high blood pressure is present before pregnancy, is diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation, or persists beyond 12 weeks postpartum.

 

Ref: Page no 1778, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia
Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
Acute myeloid leukemia
Chronic myelogenous leukemia

questions.text: The given peripheral smear is associated with which of the following leukemias? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic lymphocytic leukemia

 

The peripheral smear findings point toward a diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

 

The blood contains large numbers of small round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm. Some of these cells are usually disrupted in the process of making smears, producing so-called smudge cells. Lymphocytes are of same size and configuration with a uniform appearance called as "convent-girl" appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL): The peripheral smear in ALL typically shows a high number of lymphoblasts, which are larger than normal lymphocytes and have a high nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio. There would be an absence of smudge cells, which are characteristic of CLL.

 

Option C. Acute myeloid leukemia (AML): AML is characterized by the presence of myeloblasts in the peripheral blood smear. These cells are larger, have more cytoplasm, and may contain Auer rods. Again, smudge cells are not a feature of AML.

 

Option D. Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML): The peripheral smear in CML shows a full spectrum of myeloid cells, from myeloblasts to mature neutrophils, often with an increase in basophils and eosinophils. Smudge cells are not a characteristic finding in CML.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following features of stroke need not be treated? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neglect

 

Neglect after a stroke, often presenting as a lack of awareness of one side of the body, does not typically require direct medical treatment. While it may indicate a more severe stroke and can impact rehabilitation, many patients improve as they recover from other stroke symptoms. Therapy focuses on aiding patients in adapting to or compensating for this deficit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dysphagia: Must be treated to prevent complications like aspiration pneumonia.

 

Option B. Spasticity: Requires management with medications (baclofen, tizanidine) or physical therapy to improve mobility and reduce discomfort.

 

Option C. Fever: Should be treated promptly as it can exacerbate brain injury and worsen outcomes in stroke patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While neglect is a common symptom following a stroke, it does not typically require specific medical treatment but rather supportive care and rehabilitation to help the patient adapt. Other physical symptoms such as dysphagia, spasticity, and fever require active medical management to prevent complications.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of facial puffiness and frothy urine. Given below is the histological image of the condition. What do you think is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Membranous nephropathy

 

The image is characteristic of membranous nephropathy. The given hematoxylin and eosin (H&E)-stained image shows uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall. (Intense pink color)

 

 

Membranous nephropathy is a common cause of the nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is characterized by diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall due to the accumulation of electron-dense, Ig-containing deposits along the subepithelial side of the basement membrane.

 

It is a form of chronic immune-complex-mediated disease.

 

Microscopy:

 

  • Light microscopy: The GBM is thickened without cellular proliferation.
  • Immunofluorescence microscopy: granular deposits containing lg and complement along the glomerular basement membrane
  • Electron micrograph: electron-dense subepithelial deposits (epimembranous spikes) and effacement of foot processes of podocytes

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): FSGS is characterized by segmental scarring of the glomeruli, which is not seen in the provided image. FSGS also typically presents with focal lesions rather than the diffuse thickening observed in membranous nephropathy.

 

Option C. Membranoproliferative nephritis: This condition is characterized by hypercellularity and a thickened, double-contoured glomerular basement membrane, often referred to as "tram-track" appearance, which is different from the thickened, smooth GBM seen in membranous nephropathy.

 

Option D. Dense deposit disease: Also known as Type II membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, this condition is marked by ribbon-like electron-dense deposits within the GBM, which is not consistent with the features of membranous nephropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Membranous nephropathy is characterized by uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall with subepithelial immune deposits, as evidenced by the histological image provided.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortans pathologic basis of disease, page no. 1766, 1767

questions.text: Pegloticase is used in the treatment of (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chronic gout

 

Pegloticase is a recombinant form of uricase, an enzyme that converts uric acid into allantoin, a more water-soluble substance that is easily excreted by the kidneys. Humans naturally lack this enzyme, and pegloticase is specifically designed to address the accumulation of uric acid in patients with gout.

 

Pegloticase is particularly indicated for the treatment of chronic gout in patients who have not responded to conventional therapies. Due to its potential immunogenicity, which can lead to infusion reactions including anaphylaxis, pegloticase is reserved for rare cases of refractory symptomatic chronic gout.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paralytic ileus: Paralytic ileus is a condition of impaired bowel motility. Pegloticase has no role in the treatment of paralytic ileus.

 

Option C. Psoriatic arthritis: Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis. Treatments typically include NSAIDs, DMARDs, and biologics, but not pegloticase.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disorder treated with NSAIDs, corticosteroids, DMARDs, and biologic agents. Pegloticase is not used in the management of rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Educational objective:

 

Pegloticase is used in the treatment of chronic gout, particularly in patients who have not responded to other therapies, due to its ability to lower uric acid levels by converting it to allantoin.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/. 235

questions.text: All of the following drugs act as HER-1 inhibitors except (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pertuzumab

 

  • Pertuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets HER-2 (Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2), not HER-1. 
  • It is used primarily in the treatment of HER-2 positive breast cancer.
  • HER-1 (Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 1) is also known as EGFR (Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor). 
  • Several monoclonal antibodies target EGFR, while others target different members of the HER family, such as HER-2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cetuximab: Cetuximab is an EGFR (HER-1) inhibitor used primarily in the treatment of certain types of colorectal cancer and head and neck cancer.

 

Option B. Necitumumab: Necitumumab is also an EGFR (HER-1) inhibitor, used in the treatment of metastatic squamous non-small cell lung cancer.

 

Option D. Panitumumab: Panitumumab is an EGFR (HER-1) inhibitor, used in the treatment of metastatic colorectal cancer.

 

Given this information, the drug that does not act as a HER-1 inhibitor is: 
c. Pertuzumab

questions.text: The fetal adrenal gland production of which of the following is maximum? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DHEA

 

The fetal adrenal gland primarily produces Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) and its sulfate form, DHEA-S, in significant quantities during pregnancy. DHEA and DHEA-S are essential precursors for the synthesis of estrogens. These precursors are crucial because the fetal adrenal gland produces much more DHEA-S than the maternal adrenal gland, making it the most important source of estrogen precursors for the placenta.

 

During pregnancy, these estrogens play a vital role in maintaining the pregnancy and supporting fetal development. The high production of DHEA by the fetal adrenal gland underlines its significant contribution to the endocrine environment during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cortisol: While cortisol is produced by the fetal adrenal gland, its production is not as high as DHEA. Cortisol plays a role in fetal lung maturation, but it is not produced in maximum amounts compared to DHEA.

 

Option C. Corticosterone: Corticosterone is another steroid hormone produced by the adrenal gland but in much smaller quantities than DHEA.

 

Option D. Progesterone: Progesterone is primarily produced by the placenta during pregnancy, and the adrenal gland's contribution to its levels is minimal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fetal adrenal gland produces the maximum amount of DHEA, which is a precursor for estrogen synthesis, critical for maintaining pregnancy and supporting fetal development.

questions.text: The strict anaerobe among the following is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prevotella

 

The strict anaerobe in the given options is Prevotella.

 

Prevotella spp are anaerobic, gram negative bacilli or coccobacilli.

 

Prevotella spp. are members of the oral, vaginal, and gut microbiota and are often recovered from anaerobic infections of the respiratory tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burkholderia cepacia:  Is gram-negative, aerobic bacilli belonging to pseudomonad group.

 

Option B. Yersinia enterocolitica: Are gram negative facultative anaerobes.

 

Option C. Stenotrophomonas maltophilia: Are gram-negative, aerobic bacilli belonging to pseudomonad group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prevotella species are strict anaerobes, thriving in oxygen-free environments, and are part of the normal flora of the oral, vaginal, and gut microbiota. They can be involved in various anaerobic infections, particularly of the respiratory tract.

choices.text: Statement 1 is false and Statement 2 is true
Statement 1 is true and Statement 2 is false
Both the statements are true but 2 is not the conclusion of 1
Both the statements are true and 2 is the conclusion of 1

questions.text:
Statement 1: Clinically a patient having flaccid bullae with painful erosions, will show Suprabasal split and inflammatory infiltrate in the blister cleft on histopathological examination.

 

Statement 2: Row of tombstones appearance is diagnostic of Pemphigus vulgaris (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both the statements are true but 2 is not the conclusion of 1

 

Both statements are true about Pemphigus vulgaris but statement 2 is not explaining 1.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris, a blistering autoimmune skin condition. The condition is characterized by suprabasal acantholysis (a separation of skin cells above the basal cell layer), leading to the formation of flaccid bullae with painful erosions. The "row of tombstones" appearance describes a specific histological feature of Pemphigus vulgaris.

questions.text: Which one is not a criterion for Kawasaki disease? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Purulent conjunctivitis

 

Purulent conjunctivitis is not a criterion for Kawasaki disease. Instead, the conjunctivitis seen in Kawasaki disease is non-purulent and sterile, meaning it does not produce pus, and cultures are negative.

 

Kawasaki disease is an acute, self-limited vasculitis that predominantly affects children. The diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease include the presence of fever for at least five days, along with at least four of the following five clinical features:

 

  1. Bilateral non-purulent conjunctival injection (conjunctivitis): This is a common feature in Kawasaki disease, but it is non-purulent (does not produce pus).
  2. Changes in the lips and oral cavity: This includes strawberry tongue (a red, bumpy tongue), erythema, and cracking of the lips.
  3. Polymorphous rash: A rash of various forms can be present.
  4. Cervical lymphadenopathy: Typically unilateral and larger than 1.5 cm in diameter.
  5. Changes in the extremities: This includes erythema of the palms and soles, edema of the hands and feet, and later desquamation (peeling) of the skin.

 

TOC - IVIG (Intravenous Immunoglobulin) ± Aspirin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rash: A polymorphous rash is one of the key diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease.

 

Option C. Lymphadenopathy: Cervical lymphadenopathy is another diagnostic criterion, usually unilateral and larger than 1.5 cm.

 

Option D. Strawberry tongue: Changes in the lips and oral cavity, including strawberry tongue, are diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kawasaki disease is diagnosed based on a set of clinical criteria, including non-purulent conjunctivitis, rash, lymphadenopathy, and changes in the oral cavity such as strawberry tongue. Purulent conjunctivitis is not a feature of Kawasaki disease.

choices.text: Monitoring of lithium therapy
Monitoring of carbamazepine therapy
Administration of long acting depot antipsychotics
Administration of nicotine patches

questions.text: Z track technique is used for (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Administration of long acting depot antipsychotics

 

Z track technique is a technique used for intramuscular injection.


During Z track technique, skin is stretched to one side before injecting the needle so that the point of injection and point of deposition of drug are not in straight line. This decreases the risk of efflux back of drug.

 

Advantages of Z track technique –

 

  • It will not cause any pigmentation
  • Lithium and carbamazepine are oral drugs and monitoring is done by taking blood through intravenous route.
  • Long acting depot antipsychotics are given by intramuscular route via z-track technique.
  • Nicotine patches are applied on the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Monitoring of lithium therapy: Lithium therapy is monitored through blood tests, not intramuscular injections. Blood samples are taken intravenously to measure lithium levels.

 

Option B. Monitoring of carbamazepine therapy: Carbamazepine therapy is also monitored through blood tests. Blood samples are taken intravenously to measure carbamazepine levels, and the medication is usually taken orally.

 

Option D. Administration of nicotine patches: Nicotine patches are applied transdermally to the skin. The Z track technique is not relevant for this method of administration.

 

Educational objective:

 

The Z track technique is used for intramuscular injections, particularly for long-acting depot antipsychotics, to ensure proper deposition of the medication and prevent leakage back through the injection path.

choices.text: APGAR persists at 4-7 for > 5 minutes

questions.text: A 3.5 kg term neonate born to a mother with eclampsia, did not cry at birth. Which of the following is the criteria for perinatal asphyxia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypotonia


The essential criterion for perinatal asphyxia is hypotonia. Perinatal asphyxia occurs when the fetus or newborn suffers from oxygen deprivation (hypoxia) or inadequate perfusion (ischemia) to the organs. This condition often leads to tissue lactic acidosis and hypercarbia. Hypotonia in a newborn is a clinical indicator of neurological compromise, which is commonly associated with perinatal asphyxia. This neurological manifestation signifies decreased oxygen delivery to the brain, leading to conditions such as hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. APGAR persists at 4-7 for > 5 minutes: While a persistently low APGAR score indicates distress and potential complications, it is not a definitive criterion for diagnosing perinatal asphyxia. An APGAR score below 3, persisting for more than 5 minutes, is more indicative of significant hypoxic injury.

 

Option B. Cord pH < 7.2: A cord pH below 7.2 indicates acidosis and is a sign of distress in the newborn. However, the criteria for diagnosing perinatal asphyxia usually include a pH below 7.0, which signals severe metabolic or mixed acidosis.

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: Hypocalcemia is a metabolic disturbance that can occur in neonates but is not a specific criterion for diagnosing perinatal asphyxia. It may occur as a consequence of various conditions, including birth asphyxia, but it is not a direct indicator of the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perinatal asphyxia is characterized by neurological manifestations such as hypotonia, low APGAR scores, severe acidosis (pH < 7.0), and multiorgan dysfunction. Hypotonia in the immediate neonatal period is a critical clinical sign of potential hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy and perinatal asphyxia.

questions.text: All of the following are components of Beck's cognitive theory of depression except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Introjection

 

Introjection is a psychological process where a person unconsciously adopts the ideas or attributes of other people or objects. This is often discussed in psychoanalytic contexts, not cognitive ones.

 

It involves internalizing aspects of others, such as a child internalizing aspects of a lost parent, leading to complex emotional outcomes, which might contribute to the development of depressive feelings.

 

Other Options:

 

Beck's cognitive theory of depression posits that negative thoughts, cognitive distortions, and dysfunctional beliefs are central to the development and maintenance of depression.

 

Option A. Dysfunctional beliefs are ingrained, maladaptive beliefs developed over time, often from childhood experiences, that can trigger depression when activated by stress.

 

Option B. Cognitive distortions are systematic errors in thinking, such as all-or-nothing thinking or overgeneralization, which negatively influence one's perception of reality.

 

Option D. Automatic negative thoughts are recurring negative thoughts that occur spontaneously and contribute to the persistence of depressive symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Introjection is not a component of Beck's cognitive theory of depression; it is associated with psychoanalytic theory, which focuses on internalized feelings towards an object, such as a parent, and is less commonly used in contemporary understanding of depression.

choices.text: Aspirin & clopidogrel
Decompressive surgery
Mechanical thrombectomy

questions.text: A 53-year-old man was admitted with history of a cerebrovascular accident 2 days ago. The patient is drowsy with minimal response. CT findings is shown in the image below. What will be your next line of management? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decompressive surgery

 

The CT scan image shows significant edema and midline shift affecting more than 50% of the Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) territory. This extensive edema, along with the patient's low Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score, indicates severe brain swelling and increased intracranial pressure (ICP). In such cases, medical management alone (like mannitol for reducing ICP) may not be sufficient.

 

Guidelines for urgent decompression:

 

  • NIH Stroke scale > 15
  • Time < 48 hours
  • Age 18-60yrs
  • Territory infarct > 145cm3 or > 50% MCA territory
  • Informed consent that surgery improves survival but the patient may have significant disability.

 

Medical management of brain edema and increased intracranial pressure (ICP) may not be successful when significant swelling occurs in the cerebral or cerebellar hemisphere.

 

Therefore, a decompressive craniectomy should be considered to relieve the mass effect of the swollen cerebral or cerebellar hemisphere on the thalamus, brainstem and network projections to the cortex, which is manifested predominantly by decreased levels of arousal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin & clopidogrel: Incorrect as these medications are used for preventing further thrombotic events but are not suitable in the acute management of severe edema and brain shift.

 

Option B. Mannitol: Incorrect for sole use in this severe case, as it might not adequately control the mass effect and high ICP shown.

 

Option D. Mechanical thrombectomy: Incorrect because the primary issue in the CT image is the significant brain swelling and herniation risk, not an occlusion that can be resolved by thrombectomy at this stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cases of significant cerebral edema with midline shift, as seen on CT in acute stroke settings, decompressive surgery is often necessary to prevent fatal outcomes and manage increased intracranial pressure effectively.

questions.text:
Which of the following equipment is required for putting intravenous cannula in a newborn?(INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. 22G cannula

  2. 24G IV cannula

  3. 5-mL syringe

  4. Adhesive tape

  5. Normal saline
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2,3,4,5

 

Explanation:

 

2. 24G IV cannula: This refers to a 24-gauge (24G) cannula, which is typically used for neonates and infants due to its smaller diameter, making it suitable for their small and fragile veins.

3. 5-mL syringe: While placing an IV cannula, it's essential to have a syringe attached. The syringe helps to test the patency of the cannula once it's in the vein (flashback of blood can be seen), and it also assists in gently flushing the cannula with normal saline to ensure it's correctly positioned.

4. Adhesive tape: Once the cannula is in position, adhesive tape or a securement device is necessary to stabilize and fix the cannula in place, preventing it from dislodging.

5. Normal saline: Normal saline is used for flushing the cannula once it's in place to ensure patency. It's also utilized to keep the cannula patent if it's not immediately hooked up to an IV line.

 

Other Option:

 

1. 22G IV cannula: A 22-gauge (22G) cannula is larger and may be used for older infants or children but is often too large for a newborn's tiny veins. Hence, it is not typically used for neonates.

 

Educational Objective :

 

For placing an IV cannula in a newborn, the equipment required includes a 24G needle, a 5-mL syringe, adhesive tape, and normal saline.

choices.text: Corticosteroids increase bronchial responsiveness to salbutamol
Corticosteroids cause direct bronchodilatation when used with xanthine
Corticosteroids indirectly increase the effect of xanthine on adenosine receptor
Corticosteroids increase mucous secretion.

questions.text: Acute exacerbation of asthma was comprehended, salbutamol was prescribed, however, no improvement was noticed. Intravenous corticosteroids and aminophylline were given and the condition improved. What is the probable mechanism by which the corticosteroids would have improved the condition? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Corticosteroids increase bronchial responsiveness to salbutamol

 

Corticosteroids are not bronchodilators by itself, but they are used in acute exacerbation of asthma because they decrease the secretion of mucous, decrease the inflammatory mediators and also increase the responsiveness of the β receptors to the action of the β2 agonists. Therefore, it can be said that Corticosteroids improved the condition by increasing the airway responsiveness to salbutamol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Corticosteroids cause direct bronchodilatation when used with xanthine: This is incorrect. Corticosteroids do not cause direct bronchodilation. Their primary role is to reduce inflammation and enhance the effects of bronchodilators.

 

Option C. Corticosteroids indirectly increase the effect of xanthine on adenosine receptor: This is incorrect. Corticosteroids do not have a direct or indirect effect on the xanthine (aminophylline) action on adenosine receptors.

 

Option D. Corticosteroids increase mucous secretion: This is incorrect. Corticosteroids actually decrease mucus secretion, which helps to clear the airways and improve airflow during an asthma exacerbation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corticosteroids improve the condition of patients with acute asthma exacerbation by increasing the bronchial responsiveness to β2 agonists like salbutamol, reducing inflammation, and decreasing mucus secretion.

choices.text: It confirms that the person does not have the disease
It suggests that if the disease is rare, the person surely has the disease
It confirms that the person has the disease if the disease is common
It is an expected finding in case the disease is prevalent

questions.text: A sensitive diagnostic test for a certain disease returns a positive result for a patient. What statement accurately describes the significance of a positive result from the sensitive test? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) It confirms that the person has the disease if the disease is common

 

  • If a sensitive test yields a positive result, it indicates the presence of the disease, especially when the disease is prevalent.
  • The sensitivity of a screening test refers to its capacity to accurately identify individuals with the disease.
  • In simpler terms, sensitivity measures the test's capability to correctly spot true positives (TP) among all cases of the disease (TP+FN). 

 

Sensitivity = TP / TP + FN X 100

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It confirms that the person does not have the disease: Incorrect. A sensitive test returning a positive result indicates the presence, not the absence, of the disease.

 

Option B. It suggests that if the disease is rare, the person surely has the disease: Incorrect. If the disease is rare, the positive predictive value (PPV) might be low, and the result may be less reliable.

 

Option D. It is an expected finding in case the disease is prevalent: Incorrect. While a positive result is more likely in a prevalent disease, it does not solely rely on sensitivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A positive result from a highly sensitive test confirms the presence of the disease, particularly when the disease is common.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is not supplied by the structure marked by red arrow? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Superior oblique

 

The superior oblique muscle is not supplied by the oculomotor nerve, which is the structure highlighted in the figure. Superior oblique muscle is supplied by the trochlear nerve.

 

All the extraocular muscles are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except:

 

  • ﻿﻿Lateral rectus which is supplied by abducens (VI) nerve
  • ﻿﻿Superior oblique which is supplied by trochlear (IV) nerve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior rectus: This muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve, which is the structure indicated by the red arrow in the image. This muscle helps in elevating the eye.

 

Option C. Medial rectus: Also supplied by the oculomotor nerve, this muscle is responsible for adducting the eye towards the nose.

 

Option D. Levator palpebrae superioris (LPS): Innervated by the oculomotor nerve, the LPS is essential for elevating the upper eyelid, enabling the opening of the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Inj. Amphotericin B for 4-8 weeks, followed by oral itraconazole
﻿﻿﻿Inj. Amphotericin B for 8 weeks, followed by oral posaconazole
﻿﻿﻿Inj. Fluconazole, followed by oral fluconazole
﻿﻿﻿Inj. Amphotericin B, followed by flucytosine

questions.text: A patient presented with periorbital pain and nasal discharge. On examination, the findings shown in the image below. She is an immunocompromised patient currently on HAART. Which of the following antifungal regimen should be prescribed to this patient along with HAART? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Inj. Amphotericin B for 8 weeks, followed by oral posaconazole

 

An immunocompromised patient presenting with peri-orbital swelling and black necrosed lesion is suggestive of mucormycosis, an opportunistic fungal infection.

 

  • Amphotericin B is the first-line treatment for mucormycosis due to its broad-spectrum antifungal activity. Posaconazole is used for consolidation therapy following initial treatment with Amphotericin B, especially in cases of severe infection or in immunocompromised patients.
  • Treatment of the underlying immunodeficiency along with surgical debridement might be needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inj. Amphotericin B for 4-8 weeks, followed by oral itraconazole: This regimen is not the most recommended for mucormycosis. Itraconazole is less effective compared to posaconazole for mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Inj. Fluconazole, followed by oral fluconazole: Fluconazole is not effective against mucormycosis. It is primarily used for infections caused by Candida and Cryptococcus species.

 

Option D. Inj. Amphotericin B, followed by flucytosine: Flucytosine is used in combination with Amphotericin B for the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis, not mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucormycosis requires aggressive treatment with Amphotericin B followed by consolidation therapy with posaconazole, particularly in immunocompromised patients. This combination helps ensure both initial and sustained control of the fungal infection.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with the diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia was treated medically. She developed fever and tachypnea and a chest X-ray showed pulmonary infiltrates. What drug should she be given next? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone

 

The correct choice is B, Dexamethasone, because the symptoms described (fever, tachypnea, and pulmonary infiltrates) suggest the patient may be experiencing differentiation syndrome, which can occur following the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) with agents like Arsenic trioxide and All-Trans retinoic acid. Differentiation syndrome is characterized by such symptoms and can improve with the administration of Dexamethasone. Dexamethasone is also used intrathecally in children for treating Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML), indicating its relevance in managing severe inflammatory reactions in hematological conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytarabine: This option is incorrect as Cytarabine is primarily used in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia and not specifically indicated for the management of differentiation syndrome in APML.

 

Option C. Doxorubicin: Incorrect because Doxorubicin is utilized for its efficacy against various cancers including Hodgkin's disease, cancer of the breast, and thyroid but is not suitable for treating differentiation syndrome in APML. It is also known for its cardiotoxic effects.

 

Option D. Methotrexate: Incorrect as it is not recommended in the treatment regimen for APML and does not address the immediate complications of differentiation syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexamethasone is used to manage differentiation syndrome in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia, characterized by symptoms like fever, tachypnea, and pulmonary infiltrates following treatment with specific leukemia drugs

 

Reference - Harrison/Oncology/Acute leukemia/chap100-743

questions.text: All of the following viral vaccines are types of Live vaccines except: [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Hepatitis B vaccine

 

Hepatitis B vaccine is not a live vaccine. Hepatitis B vaccine was earlier available as a killed form, but nowadays it is available as a subunit recombinant plasma-derived or yeast-derived vaccine. This makes it a subunit vaccine, not a live vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classification of vaccines

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in MEN 2B syndrome? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medullary thyroid carcinoma

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B) is a genetic syndrome characterized by the presence of specific tumors and physical features. This syndrome is often referred to as "Triple M syndrome" because it commonly presents with three key features: mucosal neuromas, a marfanoid body habitus, and medullary thyroid carcinoma. In addition, pheochromocytomas may also occur.

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) is a type of thyroid cancer originating from the parafollicular cells (C cells) that produce calcitonin. MTC is a hallmark of MEN 2B, making it one of the primary diagnostic criteria for the syndrome.

 

The condition is associated with mutations in the RET proto-oncogene, specifically the codon 918 mutation on chromosome 10, which leads to the development of these tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Café au lait spot: Café au lait spots are not characteristic of MEN 2B syndrome. These pigmented skin lesions are more commonly associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) and, in some cases, tuberous sclerosis.

 

Option C. Parathyroid adenoma: Parathyroid adenomas are typically seen in patients with MEN 1 and MEN 2A syndromes, not in MEN 2B. These adenomas cause hyperparathyroidism, which is not a feature of MEN 2B.

 

Option D. Optic nerve glioma: Optic nerve gliomas are primarily associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). They are not a feature of MEN 2B syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most significant feature of MEN 2B syndrome is the presence of medullary thyroid carcinoma, alongside mucosal neuromas and a marfanoid body habitus, often linked to mutations in the RET proto-oncogene

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient undergoes an appendicectomy procedure. Two days later, she complains of severe abdominal pain and is found to have a collection of blood in the abdomen on examination. On exploration, it is discovered that a particular artery should have been ligated during the surgery to prevent this complication. Which of the following arteries should have been ligated during the appendicectomy procedure to prevent postoperative hemorrhage in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ileocolic artery

 

The ileocolic artery is a branch of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) that supplies blood to the appendix and the cecum. During an appendicectomy procedure, it is crucial to identify and ligate the appendicular branch of ileocolic artery to prevent postoperative hemorrhage. Failure to do so can result in bleeding complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right colic artery: The right colic artery is another branch of the SMA that supplies blood to the ascending colon and the right side of the transverse colon. Ligating the right colic artery is not a standard part of an appendicectomy procedure.

 

Option C. Superior rectal artery: The superior rectal artery is a branch of the inferior mesenteric artery and supplies blood to the rectum. It is not directly related to an appendicectomy procedure.

 

Option D. Superior mesenteric artery: The superior mesenteric artery is a major blood vessel that supplies blood to various parts of the small intestine, including the jejunum and ileum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the removal of the appendix, the inferior branch of the ileocolic artery needs to be ligated at the base of the appendix to prevent postoperative hemorrhage. The appendicular artery typically arises directly from the ileocolic artery and supplies the appendix through multiple small branches. If not ligated, the appendicular artery may cause bleeding complications.

questions.text: Given is a model of embryological development of the heart. Which structure develops from the area marked with red arrow?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Infundibulum

 

Explanation:

 

The marked object is the conus cordis (middle part of bulbus cordis). From this structure, the heart's infundibulum emerges.

 

The heart is represented in the model at the stage of embryology where both heart tubes have merged and are undergoing dextro-looping, or bending. During day 23 of intrauterine life, this occurs.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atria: The atria of the heart primarily develop from the primitive atrial chamber or sinus venosus, not from the conus cordis. The sinus venosus will contribute to the formation of the smooth parts of the right and left atria. The atrial appendages or auricles, however, develop from the primitive atrium.

 

Option B. Left Ventricle: The left ventricle arises mainly from the primitive ventricle of the embryonic heart tube. As the heart develops, the primitive ventricle gives rise to the muscular parts of both the left and right ventricles, but primarily the left.

 

Option D. Interventricular septum:The interventricular septum separates the right and left ventricles. It has a muscular part and a membranous part. The muscular part primarily develops from the growth of the myocardium of the primitive ventricle. The conus cordis and the truncus arteriosus contribute to the formation of the membranous part of the interventricular septum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The infundibulum, also referred as the conus arteriosus or the outflow tract, develops from the conus cordis. It represents the smooth-walled, anterior portion of the right ventricle and leads to the pulmonary trunk in the mature heart.

questions.text: Pacinian corpuscle is stimulated by which of the following? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pressure

 

Pacinian corpuscle is stimulated by pressure.

 

  • Pacinian corpuscles (Vater-Pacini or lamellar corpuscles) are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptors for vibration and deep pressure and are essential for proprioception.
  • They can be found throughout the whole body; however, it is the hands and feet where they occur most numerously and tightly grouped.
  • They are composed of a nerve ending which is encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue that give it an onion-like appearance and are present in the dermis. The sensory nerves from cutaneous mechanoreceptors are myelinated Aα and Aβ fibers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pain: Incorrect. Pain is detected by nociceptors, not Pacinian corpuscles.

 

Option B. Temperature: Incorrect. Temperature is detected by thermoreceptors, not Pacinian corpuscles.

 

Option C. Touch: Incorrect. Touch is detected by various mechanoreceptors, including Meissner's corpuscles and Merkel discs, but Pacinian corpuscles specifically detect deep pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pacinian corpuscles are specialized mechanoreceptors that detect deep pressure and vibration, playing a crucial role in proprioception and providing sensory feedback about the physical environment.

choices.text: New drug application is filed after phase 4
Phase 4 is also called post-marketing surveillance
Phase 3 are open label studies without any blinding
Phase 2 is done on healthy individuals

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding clinical trials? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Phase 4 is also called post-marketing surveillance

 

Phase 4 clinical trials are also called post-marketing surveillance. This statement is correct. Phase 4 trials are conducted after a drug has been approved and marketed to monitor its long-term effectiveness and safety.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. New drug application is filed after phase 4: This statement is incorrect. The New Drug Application (NDA) is filed after successful completion of Phase 3 clinical trials, not Phase 4. Phase 4 occurs after the drug has been approved and marketed.

 

Option C. Phase 3 are open label studies without any blinding: This statement is incorrect. Phase 3 clinical trials are typically randomized and double-blinded to eliminate bias and ensure robust results. Open label studies, where both the participants and investigators know which treatment is being administered, are less common in Phase 3 trials.

 

Option D. Phase 2 is done on healthy individuals: This statement is incorrect. Phase 2 clinical trials are conducted on patients who have the condition that the drug is intended to treat. Phase 1 trials, on the other hand, are usually done on healthy volunteers to assess safety and dosage.


Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of biophysical profile? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Daily fetal movement count

 

Explanation:

 

Daily fetal movement count (DFMC) is not a component of the BPP. DFMC, often assessed using Cardiff’s count of 10, is a separate method for monitoring fetal movements.

 

  • The Biophysical Profile (BPP) is a comprehensive test used in the assessment of fetal wellbeing. It includes five components, which are scored using the Manning score:
    1. Non-stress test (NST)
    2. Amniotic fluid volume (AFV)
    3. Fetal movements
    4. Fetal tone
    5. Fetal breathing movements
  • A low Manning score is indicative of fetal hypoxia and may necessitate further clinical intervention.
  • Additionally, the Modified Biophysical Profile (BPP) includes only two components:
    1. Non-stress test (NST)
    2. Amniotic fluid index (AFI)

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Amniotic fluid volume: Amniotic fluid volume is a component of the BPP and helps assess the amount of amniotic fluid surrounding the fetus.

 

Option B. Fetal tone: Fetal tone is another component of the BPP, assessing the baby's muscle tone.

 

Option D. Non-stress test: Non-stress test (NST) is part of the BPP and evaluates the fetal heart rate in response to fetal movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Biophysical Profile (BPP) consists of five components: NST, AFV, fetal movements, fetal tone, and fetal breathing movements. Daily fetal movement count (DFMC) is not part of the BPP.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg 342, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 122

questions.text:
Arrange the steps of intubation in the correct order, starting from the initial preparation to confirmation of placement: 

 

1. Introduction of laryngoscope
2. Check breath sounds with a stethoscope
3. Position the neck with extension and flexion
4. Inflate the tube cuff
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3142

 

The proper sequence for intubation is as follows:

 

3. Position the neck with extension and flexion - This positioning provides a clear view of the vocal cords by aligning the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes.

 

1. Introduction of laryngoscope - After positioning, the laryngoscope is introduced to visualize the vocal cords and facilitate tube placement.

 

4. Inflate the tube cuff - Once the endotracheal tube is correctly placed, the cuff is inflated to secure the airway.

 

2. Check breath sounds with a stethoscope - Auscultation ensures correct placement by verifying that both lungs are being ventilated equally.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The correct sequence for intubation is Positioning the neck → Introducing the laryngoscope → Inflating the tube cuff → Confirming with breath sounds.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea presents to the outpatient department with complaints of an inability to pass urine and cyclical abdominal pain. On examination, a bluish hue is observed in the vagina. What is the most likely cause of her condition? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Imperforate Hymen

 

The features in this case pointing to imperforate hymen are:

 

  • Primary amenorrhea with cyclical pain (cryptomenorrhea)
  • Urinary retention
  • Bluish hue/bulge in vagina
  • Adolescent age group

 

The bluish hue is pathognomonic of imperforate hymen as the collected menstrual blood (hematocolpos) is visible through the thin hymenal membrane.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Transverse vaginal septum: While it can present similarly like imperforate hymen, a transverse vaginal septum is thicker and would not show the characteristic bluish hue. An MRI would be needed for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome: This condition involves absence of uterus. There would be no menstrual blood collection and thus no cyclical pain or bluish hue, as there is no uterus to generate menstrual flow.

 

Option D. OHVIRA syndrome: This presents with normal menstruation as there is only partial obstruction of vagina (hemivagina) and uterine didelphys. Patients typically have gradually worsening dysmenorrhea and may develop endometriosis. It is associated with ipsilateral renal agenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Imperforate hymen presents with primary amenorrhea, cyclical abdominal pain, and urinary retention in adolescent girls. The pathognomonic finding is a bluish bulge in the vagina due to collected menstrual blood (hematocolpos).

questions.text: The Thymus gland is specialized in identifying the molecules of the Major Histocompatibility Complex that are presented to it. It discerns whether these cells belong to the body's own or are of foreign origin. Which specific gene is accountable for this function? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AIRE

 

Autoimmunity refers to immune reactions against self-antigens. Normal persons are unresponsive (tolerant) to their own (self) antigens, and autoimmunity results from a failure of self-tolerance.

 

Self-tolerance involves two broad mechanisms: Central Tolerance and Peripheral Tolerance.

 

AIRE (Autoimmune regulator) stimulates expression of some peripheral tissue-restricted self-antigens in the thymus and is critical for deletion of immature T cells specific for these self-antigens. Mutations in the AIRE gene are the cause of an autoimmune polyendocrinopathy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. NOTCH1: NOTCH1 plays a role in cell growth and division (proliferation), maturation (differentiation), and self-destruction (apoptosis).

 

Option B. E2A: E2A proteins function by recruiting proteins that drive epigenetic remodeling that precedes transcription.

 

Option C. Rag ½: Recombination-activating genes RAG 1 and RAG 2 initiate the molecular processes that lead to lymphocyte receptor formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The AIRE gene is crucial for promoting self-tolerance by ensuring that developing T cells in the thymus are exposed to self-antigens, thus preventing autoimmune diseases.

choices.text: Partial fixation of footplate of stapes

questions.text: What causes maximum hearing loss? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ossicular discontinuity with intact TM

 

Ossicular discontinuity with intact tympanic membrane causes maximum hearing loss (around 50 dB) because:

 

  • Sound waves can only travel through the ossicular chain when it is intact
  • When there's a break in the ossicular chain, sound transmission is completely interrupted
  • With intact TM, there's no alternative pathway for sound to reach the inner ear
  • The sound waves get dampened at the point of discontinuity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otitis media with effusion

 

  • Causes mild conductive hearing loss (30-35 dB)
  • Middle ear filled with serous fluid still allows some sound transmission
  • Common in children with adenoid hypertrophy blocking Eustachian tube

 

Option B. Partial fixation of footplate of stapes

 

  • Represents early otosclerosis
  • Causes mild conductive hearing loss as stapes can still move partially
  • Less severe than complete ossicular discontinuity

 

Option D. Malleus-incus disruption with TM disruption

 

  • Causes around 40 dB hearing loss
  • Less severe than option C because sound waves can reach round window directly through the perforation
  • Provides an alternative pathway for sound transmission

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ossicular discontinuity with intact tympanic membrane causes maximum hearing loss (50 dB) because sound waves have no alternative pathway to reach the inner ear.
